title: County Health Snapshots
text:
View and download state- and county-level data for measures of Population Health and Well-being and Community Conditions based on the UWPHI Model of Population Health. Snapshots are easy to use and don’t require data or programming expertise.



We’re currently developing this tool, and it is not yet final. For now, you can view a preview below or explore it yourself here.
We welcome your help in troubleshooting and improving this tool. You can see planned updates and suggest changes on the app’s GitHub Issues page.
Thank you for your collaboration!



Preview of the County Snapshot, coming summer 2026

title: Contribution Guidelines
text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the County Health Open-Source Project! There are many ways to get involved. Below we’ve highlighted just some of the ways we invite you to participate.

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
Measure calculations repository
The measure calculations repository is the core engine behind CHR&R data. Following funding loss, we especially welcome contributions that help extend calculations beyond 2025/2026.

You can:

Add publicly available raw data for years beyond 2025/2026
Update calculation scripts to accommodate new data
Flag broken data sources or links
Propose alternative publicly accessible data sources if original sources are no longer available
Improve reproducibility, performance, or documentation of workflows



Important context:
Contributions should prioritize transparency, traceability, and alignment with historical methods
If methods change due to data availability, clearly document the change and its implications
We ask that you aim to contribute a measure in its entirety – in other words, if possible, please provide raw data, any necessary inputs, a clearly documented script for completing calculations, and a finalized measure dataset for any measure that you undertake.


How to contribute:
Submissions are reviewed before acceptance. To submit a contribution to the repository:

Start by opening an Issue describing:

The measure of health
The data source
Years covered
Any deviations from prior methods

Fork the repository and create a feature branch
Run calculation scripts locally and validate outputs
Update documentation to reflect changes
Submit a pull request with a clear summary and notes

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
County Snapshot
Contributions to the County Snapshot focus on usability, accuracy, and clarity.
You can:

Report bugs (e.g., filters not working, incorrect values, display issues)
Suggest usability or accessibility improvements
Propose new comparisons, tools, or explanatory text
Flag inconsistencies between the app and published data or documentation


How to contribute:

Open an Issue on the County Snapshot repository

If reporting a bug, please include clear reproduction steps, screenshots if possible, and the browser/device used.
For feature requests, briefly describe the public health use case.

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
countyhealthR package
Contributions to countyhealthR focus on functionality, reliability, and analyst experience.
You can:

File bugs related to data access, function outputs, or errors
Suggest or implement new helper functions
Improve documentation, examples, or vignettes
Add tests or improve error messaging


How to contribute:

Open an Issue to report bugs or discuss proposed changes
For code contributions:

Fork the repository
Create a feature branch
Follow tidyverse-style conventions where possible
Include documentation updates and tests when relevant
Submit a pull request referencing the related issue

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
Archived Data & Documentation 
Archived materials are intended for reuse, extension, and storytelling. 
You can: 

Use archived data to study trends, policy impacts, or health inequities 
Combine archived CHR&R data with new data sources 
Develop teaching materials, dashboards, or advocacy tools 
Share how you are using the data to inform local or regional decision-making 


How to contribute: 

Participate in the community discussion forum 
Share projects, analyses, or visualizations in the Show & Tell section 
Include links and citations to our archived data wherever possible

title: Contribution Guidelines
text:
Community Norms 

Be respectful and constructive 
Assume good intent 
Document decisions and tradeoffs clearly 
Prioritize equity, transparency, and public health impact 

We are especially committed to building an open-source community that is useful with or without deep GitHub or data expertise. 
Thank you for contributing to the future of county-level health data.

title: The CHR&R Archives
text:
CHR&R served as a trusted national resource for understanding the factors that influence health and equity across U.S. communities. Through annually updated measures, transparent methods, and accessible data tools, CHR&R helped local leaders, researchers, and residents explore how where we live, learn, work, and play shapes health outcomes.
With the planned retirement of the CHR&R website at the end of December 2026, many of the data-related materials that supported this work will no longer be hosted on the primary site. Recognizing the enduring value of these materials, this archive aims to preserve them for continued use by public health practitioners, analysts, students, and anyone interested in community health research.

title: The CHR&R Archives
text:
Resources
County Health Rankings & Roadmaps Zenodo Repositories

Measure calculation codes: scripts and workflows to calculate all CHR&R measure from the latest annual release
Datasets: Versioned releases of CHR&R datasets for each year (2010-2025), each with a DOI for citation and direct download. There are two primary repositories: one contains human readable Excel files and the other contains relational files with metadata
Methods and source documentation: static archive of measure definitions, source descriptions, and calculation notes from past releases

countyhealthR is an R package that enables programmatic, reproducible access to archived CHR&R data from 2010 to 2025. It is currently available on GitHub, expected on CRAN by April 2026.
Publications and White Papers:  Past technical reports and methods papers describing the CHR&R model, measures, and methods.
What Works for Health Archives (COMING SOON): Curated, evidence-informed summaries of policies, programs, and strategies shown to improve health and equity, last updated in 2025.

title: About Us
text:
About CHOP
The County Health Open-source Project is a collaborative space for researchers, public health practitioners, and data-users who care about keeping county-level health data transparent, reproducible, and available for public use, now and into the future. Our goal is to empower users to take our validated code, methods, and inputs and use them to calculate, update, and extend health measures as new data become available.  
Community members can expect documented workflows, opportunities to ask questions and troubleshoot in the Discussion Forum, and a supportive “Show and Tell” space to share wins, analyses, and lessons learned. We encourage dissemination and public sharing of derivative data products and tools, and we see reuse, adaptation, and iteration as signs of a healthy ecosystem. Whether you’re reproducing existing measures, refreshing them for future years, or building something entirely new, you’re invited to learn and build with us. Let’s keep this important public data alive together!


About CHR&R
County Health Rankings & Roadmaps (CHR&R) has drawn attention to why there are differences in health within and across communities. The program highlighted policies and practices that can help everyone be as healthy as possible. CHR&R aimed to grow a shared understanding of health, equity and the power of communities to improve health for all. This work was rooted in a long-term vision where all people and places have what they need to thrive. 
CHR&R was committed to creating resources and tools that support community-led efforts to accurately diagnose core problems, understand and account for historical context and implement evidence-informed solutions. CHR&R was proud to provide a snapshot of the health of nearly every county in the nation and trove of resources help improve conditions for all.
The CHR&R program and website will officially end in December 2026.


Contact

title: County Health Open-source Community
text:
Researchers, public health practitioners, data analysts, and anyone who uses county-level health data for research, policy, or community impact. If you care about transparent, reproducible, and accessible public health data, we invite you to join our community.



A collaborative space where users can access validated code, methods, and inputs to calculate, update, and extend county-level health measures. Community members have access to:

Documented workflows for reproducible analysis
A Discussion Forum for questions and troubleshooting
A Show and Tell space to share successes, lessons, and analyses

We encourage public sharing, reuse, and adaptation of derivative data products and tools. Whether you’re reproducing existing measures, refreshing them for new years, or building entirely new analyses, this is a place to learn and build together. Check out the Contribution Guidelines to see how you can get involved.



The project is expected to be fully launched by Summer 2026, and the community will continue to grow and evolve as new health datasets become available.



All of our code, discussion forums, and resources live on GitHub, so anyone can access, use, and build upon them from anywhere in the world.



Users of CHR&R data have consistently expressed the importance of keeping these data accessible and usable for research, policy, and community decision-making. By making tools, code, and workflows open-source, we ensure county-level health data remain transparent, reproducible, and alive for current and future use. Our goal is to empower the community to continue producing, updating, and extending these important measures of health independently.

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text: Welcome to the County Health Open-Source Project (CHOP), a community-driven effort to preserve, update, and extend the County Health Rankings & Roadmaps (CHR&R) data after the program concludes in December 2026. For more than a decade, CHR&R has helped communities understand the factors that shape health and equity. This project ensures that its data, methods, and tools remain accessible.

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Our Mission

Keep 15+ years of county health data accessible 
Provide user-friendly ways to explore county-level information on health and the conditions that shape health 
Support transparent, open methods and reproducible workflows 
Build a community-based effort to continue producing CHR&R measures beyond 2026

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
Data Availability
Beginning in March 2026, The CHR&R Archives will include:

CHR&R datasets from 2010 through 2025
A repository of code used to calculate CHR&R measures
Methods, source documentation, data tools, and more

title: County Health Open-Source Project
text:
New Features
Additional tools to be finalized throughout 2026 include:

County Health Snapshots

A user-friendly dashboard to view and download state and county-level data produced by CHR&R

County Health Open-source Community

A community-driven effort to extend CHR&R data into 2027 and beyond. See our Contribution Guidelines to learn more.



Countyhealthrankings.org will be available through December 2026. We encourage users to download datasets and technical documentation available on our website before the end of the year. This page will be updated regularly with additional resources.
These resources have been developed and curated by County Health Rankings & Roadmaps team members.
